thread.title: Federal Judge Deals A Big Blow To President Trump
thread.title_full: Federal Judge Deals A Big Blow To President Trump

title: Federal Judge Deals A Big Blow To President Trump

organizations.name: senate floor trump cancels signing of cybersecurity

text:
President Donald Trump was hit with bad news Wednesday when a judge ruled against his business organization in a class-action lawsuit launched by former members of his Florida golf club.
The Trump Organization was ordered to pay nearly $6 million as a result of the judgment.
Politico reported Wednesday that U.S. District Court Judge Keith Marra found Trump National Jupiter Golf Club was guilty of refusing to refund membership fees to members looking to leave the club.
 
Related Stories Press Freaks After Trump Departs From White House Unexpectedly: ‘This Is Not Normal’ Senate Confirms Former Exxon CEO Tillerson As Secretary Of State Trump Tweets Photo Of Prayer After Gorsuch Announcement In his decision , Marra wrote, “The Court concludes that the Plan documents, as properly interpreted, were intended to provide club members of the resignation list with a continuing right to use the Club facilities until their membership was reissued to a new member, provided the club member was otherwise in good standing with the Club.”
The lawsuit was filed in 2013 on behalf of 65 club members who charged that the Trump Organization was guilty of breach of contract.
Attorney Alan Garten told Politico the Trump Organization plans to appeal the decision.
 
“The members who resigned were all members under Ritz-Carlton who resigned prior to Trump taking ownership. Trump purchased the club from Ritz and effectively saved it because it was in financial ruin. Notwithstanding the foregoing, we disagree with the judge’s ruling and intend to appeal it,” Garten said.
Following the judge’s decision, Brad Edwards, attorney for the club members, said, “I have never been more confident after trying a case that this would be the result. To me, it was just a matter of time before this verdict came, but I’m glad we got it.”
He added, “It’s the entire amount we asked for — to the dollar. They created their own contorted reading of a contract that allowed them to avoid the refundability of the deposits.”
The lawsuit stemmed from an assertion that, under prior ownership, the members had a “refundable” membership.
  Obama’s Statement Supporting Protests Of Trump’s Executive Order Ticks Off MSNBC Host 2 GOP Senators Vow To Oppose DeVos On Senate Floor Trump Cancels Signing Of Cybersecurity Executive Order This would let members wishing to leave the club pay dues until another member could be found to continue paying the dues.
The plaintiffs charged that when the Trump Organization purchased the property in 2013, their “refundable” status was terminated.
While Trump was not named in the lawsuit, he was deposed and his deposition was presented during the trial in August.
What do you think?
